The server/ directory is used to register API and server handlers to your application.
Nuxt automatically scans files inside these directories to register API and server handlers with Hot Module Replacement (HMR) support.
language-bash shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight

-| server/
---| api/
-----| hello.ts      # /api/hello
---| routes/
-----| bonjour.ts    # /bonjour
---| middleware/
-----| log.ts        # log all requests
Each file should export a default function defined with

language-vue shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight

Note that currently server routes do not support the full functionality of dynamic routes as
Nuxt will automatically read in any file in the
to create server middleware for your project.
Middleware handlers will run on every request before any other server route to add or check headers, log requests, or extend the event's request object.
Middleware handlers should not return anything (nor close or respond to the request) and only inspect or extend the request context or throw an error.
Nuxt will automatically read any files in the
directory and register them as Nitro plugins. This allows extending Nitro's runtime behavior and hooking into lifecycle events.
which comes with a handy set of helpers.
You can add more helpers yourself inside the
For example, you can define a custom handler utility that wraps the original handler and performs additional operations before returning the final response.
// do something before the route handler
// do something after the route handler
This feature is available from Nuxt >= 3.5

Handle file names can be suffixed with
inside a directory for structuring your code differently, this is useful to create API namespaces.
// handle GET requests for the `api/foo` endpoint
// handle POST requests for the `api/foo` endpoint
// handle GET requests for the `api/foo/bar` endpoint
Catch-all routes are helpful for fallback route handling.
For example, creating a file named
will register a catch-all route for all requests that do not match any route handler, such as
// event.context.path to get the route path: '/api/foo/bar/baz'
// event.context.params._ to get the route segment: 'bar/baz'
You can set a name for the catch-all route by using
// event.context.params.slug to get the route segment: 'bar/baz'
You can now universally call this API using:

<script setup lang="ts">
async function submit() {
  const { body } = await $fetch('/api/submit', {
    method: 'post',
    body: { test: 123 }
  })
}
</script>

The public/ directory is used to serve your website's static assets.
Use the utils/ directory to auto-import your utility functions throughout your application.
